title: 104_hr3759
content:
The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" amends income levels and ceilings on investment insurance and financing under the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Income levels are adjusted to $1,280 or less and $5,556 or more in 1994 United States dollars. The ceiling on investment insurance is increased to $25,000,000,000. The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" increases the financing ceiling to $20,000,000,000 and amends issuing authority to 2001. Policy guidance is adjusted to increase US exports and complement trade policy. Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to remove certain sentences and make changes to the composition of the Board, including the addition of the President of the Corporation, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, and the United States Trade Representative. The United States Trade Representative may designate a Deputy to serve on the Board. The amendment to Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 includes changes to the composition of the Board, with the addition of a Chairman and Vice Chairman designated by the President from among the Directors of the Board. TITLE II--TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY

SEC. 201. TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY AUTHORIZATION.

Amendment to Section 661(f)(1)(A) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 authorizes $40,000,000 for fiscal 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998.

TITLE III--EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL TRADE ADMINISTRATION

SEC. 301. EXPORT PROMOTION AUTHORIZATION.

Amendment to Section 202 of the Export Administration Amendments Act of 1985 authorizes appropriations for export promotion programs. Authorization of appropriations for export promotion programs is set at $240,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998. Additionally, a strategic export plan is to be developed by the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee is amending the Export Enhancement Act to include provisions for more coordinated export promotion services for small- and medium-sized businesses, as well as establishing priorities for promoting US exports and free market reforms in the Middle East to stimulate job growth. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will identify and eliminate overlap and duplication in Federal export promotion activities, promote better coordination between State, Federal, and private sector export promotion activities, and include these efforts in the annual report by September 30, 1997. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will report on efforts to promote private sector development in Ukraine in the 1997 annual report under the Export Enhancement Act of 1988.
